channel.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
channel.description:
I would like to know please, for running a .class file at windows startup.
Thank you.

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Ah, ok Mopar. That was another approach that I was going to take.

Basically, I wanted the person to run the .bat (I guess I’ll put the info to run the .reg in there), popup would show up confirming, restart the computer and it’d show up.

So, I guess I’ll just do it that way. Thanks guys.

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Pwnd:

I would like to know please, for running a .class file at windows startup.

it doesnt seem like he wants to edit the registry with a java app

but if you want to do that just make a .bat file for the .reg file you want to put in, and have java run the batch file

Read full topic

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Mopar, you misunderstand the question. He wants to edit the registry FROM WITHIN the java app.

item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

You wouldn’t use JNI, JNI is for embedding java into native applications. What you want to do is make API calls FROM java. Have a look at

http://www.microsoft.com/mind/0198/jdirect.asp.
http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;145679&sd=tech

EDIT: Oh shit, J/Direct is only for the Microsoft VM.
EDIT2: Shit, you were also right about using JNI to do that. Ignore the whole damn post.

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Well, a friend of mine wanted something to piss her sister off.
It was going to be a non-malicious way of pissing someone off too, but I’m trying to make it user friendly. I’m also trying to put a challenge up for myself.

Seems I’ve taken more than I can chew

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Hmm, native API calls ey… yeah that might not be so fun. Is it essential that this is run at startup? This might end up being more pain than its worth.

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Again, I’d like to do it with a Java application, or .bat. Thanks for your help though.[br][size=1]Posted at: June 28, 2006, 07:26:51 am[/size][hr]I’ve looked up on the sun forums and found out I need to use a library called JNI. This isn’t soley done in Java, either. You’d probably have to write a JNI wrapper in C in order to get it done.

Now, another thing I think I could do is open regedit using Java, perhaps and write it that way. Or, have Java run a .reg file, but I’m pretty sure that isn’t going to be any easier.

Can anyone elighten me on any of these subjects?

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @marluxia marluxia
item.description:
@marluxia wrote:

in regedit the startup thingys are located in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run

then like right click and it will say add -> Key and yea you should be able to do it from there

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:2, topic:4221”]make a batch file to run the class, then add the batch file to the startup progs, i dont know exactly how to, but i hope this helps.[/quote]I know as much as that. The part for entering it directly into the registry is the problem. Thank you, though.

Iamadam, I was hoping to do it either with the .bat, or through a Java application.

Read full topic
item.source: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File

item.title: [Question] Editting the Registry to Run a .class File
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Yeah. What he said. Just drag the .bat file to the ‘startup’ directory.(Start -> Programs -> Startup)

Read full topic

make a batch file to run the class, then add the batch file to the startup progs, i dont know exactly how to, but i hope this helps.
